Learning k𝑘kitalic_k-Determinantal Point Processes for
Personalized Ranking

Yuli Liu Qinghai University, China &
Australian National University, Australia
liuyuli012@gmail.com    Christian Walder Google Brain
Montreal, Canada
cwalder@google.com    Lexing Xie Australian National University, Australia &
Data61 CSIRO, Australia
lexing.xie@anu.edu.au
Abstract

The key to personalized recommendation is to predict a personalized ranking on a catalog of items by modeling the user’s preferences. There are many personalized ranking approaches for item recommendation from implicit feedback like Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) and listwise ranking. Despite these methods have shown performance benefits, there are still limitations affecting recommendation performance. First, none of them directly optimize ranking of sets, causing inadequate exploitation of correlations among multiple items. Second, the diversity aspect of recommendations is insufficiently addressed compared to relevance.

In this work, we present a new optimization criterion Lk𝑘kitalic_kP based on set probability comparison for personalized ranking that moves beyond traditional ranking-based methods. It formalizes set-level relevance and diversity ranking comparisons through a Determinantal Point Process (DPP) kernel decomposition. To confer ranking interpretability to the DPP set probabilities and prioritize the practicality of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, we condition the standard DPP on the cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k of the DPP-distributed set, known as k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP, a less-explored extension of DPP. The generic stochastic gradient descent based technique can be directly applied to optimizing models that employ Lk𝑘kitalic_kP. We implement Lk𝑘kitalic_kP in the context of both Matrix Factorization (MF) and neural networks approaches, on three real-world datasets, obtaining improved relevance and diversity performances. Lk𝑘kitalic_kP is broadly applicable, and when applied to existing recommendation models it also yields strong performance improvements, suggesting that Lk𝑘kitalic_kP holds significant value to the field of recommender systems.

Index Terms:
Personalization, DPPs, Optimization Criterion

I Introduction

Recommender systems are ubiquitous services in many online platforms including social media and e-commerce, and play a crucial role in alleviating information overload by efficiently anticipating user preferences. This work focuses on item recommendation [1, 2], wherein the task involves generating a personalized ranking of items based on the user’s observed interactions with the system. In real-world scenarios, implicit feedback, such as clicks and views, is more readily available and collected compared to explicit feedback, e.g., ratings and reviews, making it a valuable resource for understanding user preferences.

To guide recommendation models in learning user preferences from implicit feedback, optimization objectives play a crucial role. One commonly used approach involves pointwise loss functions, e.g., binary cross entropy and squared error, which measure the discrepancy between the model’s predicted preference scores and the actual labels on an individual instance basis. Given that the goal of item recommendation is to provide a personalized ranking list to a specific user, it naturally leads to the adoption of ranking-based optimization methods. Among these, the popular pairwise ranking approach, BPR [1], assumes that an observed item ranks higher than a randomly selected unobserved (negative) item from the perspective of a specific user. Listwise ranking methods usually maximize the probability of permutation of the target list [3, 4]. In recent years, some studies have attempted to bring the correlation within items into ranking-based optimization, leading to the topic of setwise ranking. Two eminent and state-of-the-art set-based ranking methods are SetRank [5] and Set2SetRank [6]. SetRank encourages an observed item to rank in front of multiple unobserved items in each list by making use of the concept of permutation probability. Set2SetRank models the set ranking based on item to item comparison and summarization of distance measurements between items.

However, there are remain two problems in existing approaches: (i) Structure information and correlations are far from well exploited and modeled. As shown in the upper layer of Figure 1, the correlations among items are fully ignored by pointwise and pairwise learning; listwise-based models center solely on the order correlation in the ranking list of items, while the binary nature of implicit feedback obstructs the acquisition of clear order correlations; the recently proposed setwise ranking optimization models (e.g., SetRank and Set2SetRank) intend to construct set-level comparisons, but are still confined to a BPR optimization criterion, and the set ranking is obtained by summarizing the individual items in each set, rather than recognizing multiple items as a whole (i.e. set) that they are in order to more meaningfully compare them. Taking implicit feedback in Figure 1 as an illustration, a ranking optimization, which treats entire sets as cohesive entities for comparison (concrete set-level optimization), not only enables us to model explicit ranking comparisons, such as This implies that the concrete set-level optimization criterion offers a wide range of potential combinations and aids in capturing intricate dependency relationships; (ii) The objective of diversifying recommendations to mine additional interests for users, is not involved in existing optimization criterion approaches. Consequently, item recommendation models that employ these optimization objectives tend to favor popular and rather relevant items (often already known by users) [7, 8], but lose sight of raising the ranking of diversified results for broadening users’ horizons.

To overcome these limitations, this work introduces a concrete set-level optimization criterion that facilitates ranking optimization through a direct comparison of different sets’ probabilities of being a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP. Here, k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP refers to a less-explored extension of the well-established concept, Determinantal Point Process (DPP). By leveraging the balance-focused quality vs. diversity decomposition of the DPP kernel, we are able to seamlessly integrate two types of ranking comparison (i.e., relevance comparison and diversity comparison), thus offering a comprehensive measure of sets. The motivation for employing k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP lies in its ability to add ranking interpretability to DPP set probabilities, making them practically useful for achieving optimal recommendation sets. We name the proposed optimization criterion as Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, an acronym underlining its aim to learn probabilities of specific subsets under the tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution. Lk𝑘kitalic_kP presents an effective solution that acknowledges item correlations and diversity, thereby delivering an advanced recommendation model that boosts accuracy and diversity.

We summarize the contributions of this work as follows:

  • •

    We propose a concrete set-level optimization criterion, named Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, that advances ranking optimization by allowing a direct comparison of set probabilities under a tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution, moving beyond the common BPR metric. Unlike prior approaches that focus on individual items, our method provides a comprehensive comparison at the set level.

  • •

    We utilize k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP to provide ranking interpretability to DPP set probabilities, rendering them practically advantageous for ranking optimization. As a result, Lk𝑘kitalic_kP criterion recognizes item correlations and diversity, thus bolstering the accuracy and diversity of recommendations.

  • •

    By incorporating both the actual inclusion probability of an observed set and the exclusion probability of an unobserved set, we develop two distinct optimization approaches, namely Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS, which we introduce and compare.

II RELATED WORK

Item Recommendation Model. As one of the most promising technologies to build recommender systems, collaborative filtering (CF) uses the known collaborative perception of users to make recommendations [9, 10]. There are generally four varieties of CF models: matrix factorization (MF) learns user and item embeddings based on a low-rank decomposition of the user-item interaction matrix [11, 12, 13]; neural collaborative filtering replaces the inner product (a common notion of interaction in MF) with nonlinear neural networks [2, 14]; collaborative deep learning couples deep representation learning for content information and collaborative filtering for feedback matrix [15, 16]; and translation-based CF adopts latent user-item relation vectors to model interactions [17, 18]. Among these models, Graph Convolutional Network (GCN), a category of collaborative deep learning, has gained dominance due to their effective modeling of item-item relationships through graph neural networks [19, 20].

Ranking-based Optimization Criterion. BPR is the most popular pairwise approach for implicit feedback-based recommendation [21, 22], which treats each item pair independently, and ignores the correlation of multiple observed items and multiple unobserved items. The listwise approaches measure the ranking loss by calculating the distance between predicted list and true list [4, 3, 23]. SetRank [5] provides a new research perspective for listwise learning with implicit feedback by using the permutation probability to encourage one observed item to rank in front of a set of unobserved items in each list. As this work focuses on ranking-based optimization with implicit feedback and SetRank has achieved state-of-the-art ranking results [6, 24], other list-based ranking-based methods are not compared. Although Set2SetRank [6] aims to construct set-level ranking pairs by comparing the individual items in the set, it still uses the BPR optimization criterion.

DPP for Recommendation. DPP has been a preferred choice of researchers to diversify recommendations. To relieve the computation complexity issue of maximum a posteriori (MAP) for DPP generation, Chen et al. [25] develop a novel algorithm to accelerate the MAP inference for DPP, which enables multiple studies [7, 26, 27, 28] to promote diversity by generating diversified recommendation lists. As these models balance diversity and relevance by blending DPP MAP inference into complex recommendation frameworks (e.g., GAN [29] or knowledge graphs [27]) instead of focusing on ranking optimization approaches, we omit them in the Comparisons section. DPP is also used for basket completion tasks by viewing the basket completion task as a multi-class classification problem [30], in which the probability normalization and cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k are ignored, making it inapplicable to traditional recommendation.

III Methodology

In this section, we primarily focus on the Lk𝑘kitalic_kP optimization criterion, preceded by related preliminaries.

III-A Preliminaries

As this work focuses on optimization criterion design, we assume the recommendation model is available, such as matrix factorization models [1] or neural graph models [31]. To implement Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, the input (training instance) comprised of a user ID and a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP ground set with IDs of k𝑘kitalic_k positive and n𝑛nitalic_n negative items (the choices of k𝑘kitalic_k and n𝑛nitalic_n will be detailed in Section III-B) is provided at first. Once embedded, the fetched embeddings are then modeled and learned through an existing recommendation framework. The final output consists of predicted relevance scores (dot product of user-item embeddings [32, 1] or binary classification result from neural networks [2]) for k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n items. In Lk𝑘kitalic_kP optimization, we integrate these scores (quality) with the category-related diversity measurement, culminating in a tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP over entire k𝑘kitalic_k-sized subsets (i.e., C⁢(k+n,k)𝐶𝑘𝑛𝑘C(k+n,k)italic_C ( italic_k + italic_n , italic_k ) different combinations) of the k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set.

III-A2 DPP

As an elegant probabilistic model capable of modeling repulsive correlations [33], DPP has been widely studied in machine learning fields. Given a discrete set 𝒮={1,2,…,M}𝒮12…𝑀\mathcal{S}=\{1,2,\ldots,M\}caligraphic_S = { 1 , 2 , … , italic_M } (e.g., item set 𝕍𝕍\mathbb{V}blackboard_V), a DPP P𝑃Pitalic_P is a probability measure on 2𝒮superscript2𝒮2^{\mathcal{S}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the set of all subsets of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. When P𝑃Pitalic_P gives nonzero probability to empty set, there exists a matrix 𝐋∈ℝM×M𝐋superscriptℝ𝑀𝑀\mathbf{L}\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times M}bold_L ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M × italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT determining the probability of any subset S𝑆Sitalic_S of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S as

P⁢(S)=det⁡(𝐋S)det⁡(𝐋+𝐈),𝑃𝑆detsubscript𝐋𝑆det𝐋𝐈P(S)=\frac{\operatorname{det}\left(\mathbf{L}_{S}\right)}{\operatorname{det}(% \mathbf{L}+\mathbf{I})},\vspace{-0.5mm}italic_P ( italic_S ) = divide start_ARG roman_det ( bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_det ( bold_L + bold_I ) end_ARG , (1)

where 𝐋𝐋\mathbf{L}bold_L is a real, positive semi-definite kernel matrix indexed by the elements of S𝑆Sitalic_S, and 𝐈𝐈\mathbf{I}bold_I is the M×M𝑀𝑀M\times Mitalic_M × italic_M identity matrix. In this standard DPP setup, a probability is assigned to every subset (including the empty set and the entire 𝕍𝕍\mathbb{V}blackboard_V). This is not desirable in the practical problems that require explicit control over the number of items selected by the model, such as image search engines that provide a fixed-sized array of results in a page [33]. If the model based on a standard DPP gives some probability of suggesting no or every image, this is not ideal. Given this situation, an extension of DPP, i.e., k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP [34], has been proposed, which conditions a DPP on the cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k of the random set.

III-B Lk𝑘kitalic_kP Ranking

Our objective is to explore k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP in the context of optimization criterion, for providing relevant and diverse suggestions. If a purely diversity oriented kernel (whose entries are measurements of pairwise similarity) is adopted directly, the suggested results will bear no relation to user satisfaction, as only the most repulsive items (dissimilar) will be selected. Therefore, a user-specific kernel 𝐋usuperscript𝐋𝑢\mathbf{L}^{u}bold_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is required, which we obtain via the so-called quality vs. diversity decomposition of DPP kernel,

𝐋u=Diag⁡(𝐲^u)⋅𝐊⋅Diag⁡(𝐲^u).superscript𝐋𝑢⋅Diagsubscript^𝐲𝑢𝐊Diagsubscript^𝐲𝑢\mathbf{L}^{u}=\operatorname{Diag}\left(\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{u}\right)\cdot% \mathbf{K}\cdot\operatorname{Diag}\left(\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{u}\right).\vspace{-1mm}bold_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Diag ( over^ start_ARG bold_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ bold_K ⋅ roman_Diag ( over^ start_ARG bold_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (2)

Following previous studies [30, 35], the M×M𝑀𝑀M\times Mitalic_M × italic_M matrix 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K models diversity, and is learned from historical interactions. In this work, diversity is evaluated by category coverage [36, 37], an intuitive and popular diversity-related metric in implicit feedback recommendation. To associate 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K with the item category, we use diversified item sets (subsets that have a broad coverage) from users’ historical interactions as ground truth sets for training [35, 7]. In this way, a subset with more categories has a higher possibility of being selected under the DPP as compared to less diverse ones. To reduce the computational complexity of calculating a M×M𝑀𝑀M\times Mitalic_M × italic_M matrix, the diversity kernel is represented using a low-rank factorization 𝐊=𝐕⊤⁢𝐕𝐊superscript𝐕top𝐕\mathbf{K}=\mathbf{V}^{\top}\mathbf{V}bold_K = bold_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_V, learned based on the following objective function,

(3)

Here, T(+)superscript𝑇T^{(+)}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( + ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an observed diverse set and T(−)superscript𝑇T^{(-)}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( - ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents the set that contains negative items, and 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T denotes the set of paired sets used for training. 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K is not related to users, as it is only the diversity-associated kernel.

The diagonalized 𝐲^usubscript^𝐲𝑢\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{u}over^ start_ARG bold_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT plays a personalization role in the kernel 𝐋usuperscript𝐋𝑢\mathbf{L}^{u}bold_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, capturing the preference scores of user u𝑢uitalic_u (predicted by recommendation models) on entire items. The more we can learn from Equation 2 is that the quality component can be represented by different types of relevance calculation, e.g., modeling user-item interaction with inner product [1, 38] or using nonlinear neural networks [2]. This extended generality is evaluated in Section IV.

III-B1 Relevance Comparison

To achieve a set-level relevance comparison by comparing k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP subsets probabilities, we propose a specialized k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution dedicated to personalized ranking over a specific k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set (with k𝑘kitalic_k observed items in Yu+superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑢Y_{u}^{+}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and n𝑛nitalic_n random items in Yu−superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑢Y_{u}^{-}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). It is important to stress that a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP assigns probabilities only to subsets of a specific size (cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k). That is, given a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution over k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set from user u𝑢uitalic_u, we can only compare probabilities of k𝑘kitalic_k-sized subsets. We opt to define this ground set rather than directly using 𝕍𝕍\mathbb{V}blackboard_V, primarily due to considerations of computational efficiency, as learning the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities over k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n items is far more efficient than attempting to do so over the entire item set. Another fundamental motivation behind this k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n scheme lies in the necessity for our k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution to exhibit interpretability in terms of ranking. By defining the k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set, we can confer the tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution with the relevance ranking interpretation of implicitly comparing item sets’ relevance rankings. This, in turn, enables the construction of a concrete set-level optimization criterion for personalized ranking.

Specifically, given a cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k constraint, we consider two types of subsets from the k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set, i.e., the unique target subset filled with all k𝑘kitalic_k targets and other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets that are comprised of k−z𝑘𝑧k-zitalic_k - italic_z targets and z𝑧zitalic_z unobserved items (z∈ℕ+𝑧superscriptℕz\in\mathbb{N}^{+}italic_z ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and z≤k𝑧𝑘z\leq kitalic_z ≤ italic_k, and z=k𝑧𝑘z=kitalic_z = italic_k denotes a subset of unobserved items). III-B2 Diversity Comparison

To implement diversity comparison, we also need to consider the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP scenario. This consideration allows us to rank diversity in a way that is not affected by differences in set sizes, thus ensuring a fair comparison across subsets. Our methodology brings in diversity comparison based on the diverse kernel 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K. Its learning objective (Equation 3) facilitates attributing larger log-determinant values to sets encompassing a broader range of categories, thereby endowing the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution with the diversity ranking interpretation (detailed in the next section). As depicted in Figure 1, when focusing solely on the degree of diversity (categories), the corresponding model is expected to favor sets that encompass a greater number of distinct categories, that is, {v3(1,a),v6(1,b),v8(1,c)}>d{v3(1,a),v10(1,a),v11(1,a)}subscript𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑣31𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣61𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑣81𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑣31𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣101𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣111𝑎\left\{v_{3}^{(1,a)},v_{6}^{(1,b)},v_{8}^{(1,c)}\right\}>_{d}\left\{v_{3}^{(1,% a)},v_{10}^{(1,a)},v_{11}^{(1,a)}\right\}{ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } > start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. Since 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K does not bear personalization, the focus of comparison is solely on categories. We specifically evaluate the diversity of relevant items, as we aim to guide models towards diversifying the content that is of interest to users, rather than blindly pursuing diversity for its own sake.

The log-probability of Su+ksuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑢𝑘S_{u}^{+k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is proportional to the log-determinant that can be further decomposed into two components: the aggregated relevance scores and the determinant of the sub-matrix of 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K indexed by Su+ksuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑢𝑘S_{u}^{+k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is applicable when considering two target subsets drawn from different k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions, each over their unique k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground sets sampled from the same user’s implicit feedback. As these two target subsets consist of positive items, we can assume their relevance scores to be similar. Therefore, in the comparison of their k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities, the decisive factor lies in the diversity factor. Looking at Equation 3, it becomes evident that the learning process for the diverse kernel is geared towards maximizing the determinant value of diverse subset. Therefore, in a comparison scenario between two target subsets drawn from respective k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions, the one exhibiting a broader category coverage tends to possess a higher k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability. Consequently, this effect of the diversity ranking interpretation influences the unified (k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP) ranking.

The concrete set-level optimization criterion Lk𝑘kitalic_kP is thus built upon the tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution as defined in Equation 4. A target subset characterized by a broader category coverage within the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP is inclined to be assigned a higher probability than other monotonous target subsets, as shown in the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability ranking part of Figure 1, i.e., P𝐋uk⁢(v3(1,a),v6(1,b),v8(1,c))>P𝐋uk⁢(v3(1,a),v10(1,a),v11(1,a))superscriptsubscript𝑃superscript𝐋𝑢𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑣31𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣61𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑣81𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑃superscript𝐋𝑢𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑣31𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣101𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣111𝑎P_{\mathbf{L}^{u}}^{k}\left(v_{3}^{(1,a)},v_{6}^{(1,b)},v_{8}^{(1,c)}\right)>P% _{\mathbf{L}^{u}}^{k}\left(v_{3}^{(1,a)},v_{10}^{(1,a)},v_{11}^{(1,a)}\right)italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This ultimately enables item recommendation models to provide users with not only diverse but also relevant results.

It is important to note that the diverse kernel 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K is pre-trained and remains fixed throughout the process of maximizing Lk𝑘kitalic_kP. Its role lies in balancing the probabilities of the drawn target subsets, ensuring a fair and diverse representation in the recommendations. The diversity across k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets within the same k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution is not needed to consider. This is because the influence of diversity remains constant in the learning process of the optimization criterion. The objective of maximizing the relevance score of the target subset favors it with a higher ranking compared to all other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets. Therefore, the unified ranking is unaffected by the diversity level of other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets in the criterion optimizing. However, across different k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions, different target sets are all learned to enhance their relevance scores, thereby making the difference in diversity among these subsets a key determinant of their respective rankings.

To sum up, the relevance ranking interpretation signifies that a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP inherently captures the implicit ranking comparison between the target subset and other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets within a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution. On the other hand, the diversity ranking interpretation refers to the global balancing of relevance and diversity across different k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions (over various k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground sets), facilitated by the pre-learned diverse kernel. The relevance and diversity comparisons are respectively demonstrated through two ranking examples in experiments.

III-B4 Optimization Approaches (Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS)

To implement the implicit comparison of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities between the target subset and other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets within a specific ground set, it is crucial to accurately compute the probability of the target subset, which requires proper normalization. This normalization constant enables us to associate the target subset and other k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets within a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution, thereby establishing implicit competition relationships, which is

Equation 7 appropriately increases the rank of target subset, but the probability of unobserved item subsets is not explicitly integrated. Previous ranking optimization approaches, e.g., BPR, SetRank, and Set2SetRank, usually integrate a ranking pair by providing an observed instance with a randomly selected lower-ranked candidate. Unlike this common approach, we take the unobserved items into account in a probabilistic manner. In this setting,

Overall, our optimization criterion focuses on learning the probabilities of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPPs on specific ground sets for each user to optimize diversity-aware personalized ranking. Two types of optimization approaches are proposed, Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS, wherein only the positive subset and both exclusion of negative items (unobserved elements) and inclusion of positive subset are considered, respectively.

III-C Lk𝑘kitalic_kP Optimization

In the discrete DPP setting, this gradient can be computed straightforwardly,

From above formulations, it can be demonstrated that our optimization criterion based on set-level DPP probability comparison is differentiable. We therefore can apply the stochastic gradient descent based algorithms with learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η to optimize the model parameters based on sampled (u,S)∈DS𝑢𝑆subscript𝐷𝑆(u,S)\in D_{S}( italic_u , italic_S ) ∈ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In our experiments, we employ Adam and grid search η𝜂\etaitalic_η for our approaches and baselines. The gradient calculation process for Equation 10 is not presented, as Equation 10 and Equation 7 share the same basic components and parameters.

IV Experiments

To comprehensively demonstrate the superiority of our approaches, three levels of evaluations and comparisons are conducted: i) six Lk𝑘kitalic_kP based variants are proposed and evaluated; ii) two types of implementation of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP for recommendation are achieved based on Matrix Factorization (MF) and Graph Convolutional Network (GCN), and are compared with state-of-the-art baselines; iii) through verifying the improvement after applying our approaches on different recent CF methods (reworked models) over their original framework, the generality and availability can be validated.

IV-A Settings

IV-A1 Datasets

We select three common and real-world datasets as appropriate, whose category numbers and matrix densities of implicit interactions differ significantly. Amazon-review contains a series of datasets [41], comprised of a large corpus of product ratings. We select Beauty products from the collection, which have 213 categories, respectively. MovieLens is a widely used benchmark movie rating dataset. We use the version ML-1M that includes one million user ratings to 18 categories of movies. Anime dataset consists of user ratings to anime from myanimelist.net. All items in Anime are grouped into 43 categories. We transform these datasets into implicit data, where each entry is marked as 1/0, depending on whether the ratings are 5. We filter out long-tailed users and items with fewer than 10 interactions for all datasets. For each user, we randomly select 20% of the rated items as ground truth for testing, and 70% and 10% ratings constitute the training and validation set, respectively. The statistics of the three datasets are summarized in Table I. We can note that Beauty have more plentiful product categories and lower densities compared to ML and Anime.

IV-A2 Baselines and Metrics

We place all compared methods into three groups according to different levels of comparisons.
Six variants derived from k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability are given, i.e., PR, PS, NPR, NPS, PSE, and NPSE. In these methods, P means the usage of the target set inclusion probability, and N denotes the consideration of the exclusion of unobserved items. S represents a method of sampling for a training instance, i.e, selecting of k𝑘kitalic_k observed items in the order they occurred using a sliding window, along with n𝑛nitalic_n randomly selected unobserved items. R signifies random selection, i.e., randomly selecting k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n items (k𝑘kitalic_k targets and n𝑛nitalic_n un-interacted items) from user’s 1/0101/01 / 0 feedback. Inspired by the original definition of entries of DPP diversity kernel (i.e., measurements of similarity), we propose another type of formulation for diversity kernel 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K. It directly regards any two items’ embeddings as their feature vectors, which are used to calculate the similarity of item pairs following the calculation manner of Gaussian kernel [42, 43]. E denotes this new formulation of diversity factor, instead of pre-learned 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K. In the E setting, the optimization process incorporates the diversity factor directly. The intention is to learn item representations in a direction that promotes dissimilarity. For example, NPSE represents a method that uses Equation 10 (exclusion of negative items and inclusion of positive items) as the objective function trained using sequentially selected target sets, and calculates the diverse kernel based on trainable embeddings.
Four state-of-the-art and popular objective functions are included: binary cross-entropy (BCE) [2], BPR [1], SetRank [5], and S2SRank (i.e., Set2SetRank) [6]. All optimization baselines and our approaches are deployed in scenarios of MF- and GCN-based collaborative filtering (CF) recommendation models for a thorough evaluation. Our choice to implement all ranking optimization approaches using basic MF- and GCN-based CF models stems from a thoughtful rationale. As we mentioned in Section II, MF is the most common CF technique and is widely adopted as a baseline in recommendation research due to its simplicity and effectiveness in capturing latent factors and item-user interactions. GCN [38, 31, 44] has gained substantial prominence in the field of collaborative deep learning due to their ability to leverage graph structures and capture intricate item-item relationships. By selecting both MF- and GCN-based CF models for validation, we ensure a comprehensive evaluation across a spectrum of traditional and state-of-the-art approaches in item recommendation.
Two distinct seminal CF models in item recommendation field, i.e., GCMC [45] and NeuMF [2], are selected to evaluate the generality and applicability of our concrete set-level ranking optimization approaches. To take different types of CF methods into account as comprehensively as possible, we select two seminal and distinct CF models as baselines in this part of the evaluation. GCMC [45] is a seminal graph-based auto-encoder work for recommender systems, which inspired many graph neural networks based studies in the CF field, e.g., NGCF [2], lightGCN [38], and KGAT [46]. It applies negative log likelihood as loss, and a probability distribution over possible rating levels by a softmax function is produced, which is distinct from commonly used relevance calculation methods (i.e., inner product calculation and nonlinear neural networks introduced in Section III-B). NeuMF [2] is a classic and comprehensive model that combines GMF with MLP, which provides inspiration to numerous related studies [47, 48, 49]. Its relevance is predicted through classifying the interaction from a user to a specific item through nonlinear neural networks. This model is optimized based on classification-aware binary cross-entropy loss.

Two types of accuracy related metrics, i.e., NDCG@N (Nd) and Recall@N (Re), the popular and intuitive diversity metric — Category Coverage (CC) [7, 35, 37], and a harmonic F-score (F) [50, 32] metric between quality (accuracy) and diversity are adopted. As we focus on implicit feedback and there is no explicit feature under consideration, another commonly used diversity metric, i.e., intra-list distanc (ILD), [37, 51] is not adopted in evaluation. We set N∈{5,10,20}N51020\mathrm{N}\in\{5,10,20\}roman_N ∈ { 5 , 10 , 20 } for comprehensive evaluation.

IV-A3 Implementations

For the above baselines, we have carefully explored the corresponding parameters, i.e., the number of dimensions, the learning rate and regularization parameters. For a fair comparison we set the trainable embedding vectors of all compared models in this work to the same size (64), and report the best results of each model by tuning the hyperparameters on a validation set. For the CF baselines, the reworked models and original approaches both use the default parameters provided by their official source codes. A prominent variant of stochastic gradient descent method, Adam, is applied. Experiments are implemented on a NVIDIA Quadro P2000 GPU.

IV-B Comparisons and Analysis

IV-B1 Comparisons

The overall performance comparison is reported in Table II. All results are obtained by implementing GCN-based CF model, under the setting of k=n=5𝑘𝑛5k=n=5italic_k = italic_n = 5. To maintain the generality of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, we employ the basic GCN framework that learns representations from high-order connectivities referring to NGCF [31]. The bold value represents the best result of all methods. The annotation      denotes the worst performance from Lk𝑘kitalic_kP variants. The superscripts + and - label the best and worst performances out of baselines. Two types of improvements are calculated, the best performance of our variants vs. the best (max) and worst (min) performances from baselines. Three groups of key observations are made:
(i) comparison between six Lk𝑘kitalic_kP variants.

  • •

    Comparing R and S (two types of training instance construction), i.e., PR vs. PS and NPR vs. NPS, shows that selecting k𝑘kitalic_k targets in a certain sequence (S) outperforms the random selection mode (R) w.r.t. quality metrics (NDCG and Recall) on three datasets. This may be caused by the dependency among items in the target subset, as the items in sequence have clearer correlations (e.g., similar attributes, or the same category) compared to randomly constructed training targets. These correlations naturally captured by k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP in S training instances contribute to collaborative filtering. With regard to diversity results, R mode achieves better performance than S, especially on Beauty and ML datasets. This is expected, as randomly selected target subsets are endowed with more diverse correlations than is the case for S. In addition, with the same size of training instances, Lk𝑘kitalic_kP using R needs more epochs to achieve convergence compared to S, as R makes it hard to learn the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution due to increased randomness. These results verify that Lk𝑘kitalic_kP compares (relevance and diversity) rankings at set level and considers correlations within items.

  • •

    Among the two diversity factor construction methods, i.e., the pre-learned kernel 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K using Equation 3 (default type) and the item embeddings’ similarity kernel (E type), the default type approaches (i.e., PR, PS, NPR, and NPS) achieve better relevance performance than E type methods (i.e., PSE and NPSE). However, in general the diversity performance of these two types of kernels is exactly the opposite, especially in the cases of CC@10 and CC@20. The main reason behind these results is that the diversity is provided by the pre-learned diverse kernel in the default type, making it relatively easy to balance the quality and diversity. However, E type considers the diversity factor based on the intuition of expanding intra-list distance (i.e., ILD) and tries to directly learn embeddings towards two directions (quality and diversity) by regarding embeddings as feature representations of items. The weak overall performance (F) of E type indicates that explicitly learning item embeddings with two objectives finally places the recommendation system in a dilemma, and degrades performance. The noteworthy diversity results of E type further indicate that Lk𝑘kitalic_kP facilitates capturing diverse correlations not only from pre-widened category coverage (default) but also from widening ILD (E). In addition, the quality results of E type are comparable to those of the baselines (even superior to the baselines on Beauty w.r.t. Re@20) demonstrating the superiority of our approaches. The comparison between R and S above have shown that S mode is more suitable for Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, which is the reason why only the combination of S and E are listed in Table II.

  • •

    Two main Lk𝑘kitalic_kP based approaches are compared, i.e, considering only the probability of selecting a target subset (P) and considering both the inclusion of targets and exclusion of unobserved items (NP), which are based on Equation 7 and Equation 10, respectively. We only compare PS with NPS here, as other variants, e.g., R and E, are not effective enough. In general, NPS performs better than PS in both quality and diversity metrics. This suggests that explicitly taking the exclusion probability of unobserved items into account enriches the relevance ranking of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, and allows the model to capture more relationships between relevance and diversity, thereby preventing the recommendation model from suggesting monotonous results. In some cases, e.g., Re@5 and Nd@5 on ML and Re@5 on Anime, PS beats NPS. This may occur because only focusing on selecting preferred items as a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP highlights the relevance of potential positive items in the top rankings without the distraction of unobserved items. The notable performance of PS and NPS shows the prospect of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP.

  • •

    We can find that NPSE is generally weaker than PSE in relevance metrics, which is contrary to the previous comparison between P and NP. This may arise from the usage of the E type diversity factor, as adding the probabilistic learning of unobserved items in the objective function (Equation 10) makes the embedding learning process that balances quality and diversity less congruent, compared to only drawing targets (Equation 7).

(ii) comparison between our approaches and baselines.

  • •

    A significant improvement over pointwise loss (BCE) and pairwise ranking (BPR) achieved by our main Lk𝑘kitalic_kP approaches (PS and NPS) is apparent in quality metrics, exceeding 20% on Beauty, and around 10% on ML and Anime. This improvement trend also exists between Lk𝑘kitalic_kP and other set-level ranking methods (SetRank and S2SRank), i.e., around 10% on Beauty, and more than 5% on ML and Anime. This indicates that Lk𝑘kitalic_kP approaches have clear advantages in dealing with more sparse interaction matrices (Beauty) over baselines, as Beauty has the highest sparsity matrix (as calculated from Table I). The superiority of our approaches is verified with a significant boost even in comparison with the recently proposed set ranking methods.

  • •

    Regarding diversity evaluation, PS and NPS can provide more diversified suggestions for users than baselines in most cases. This means that the proposed approaches based on k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP really consider diversity in the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP learning process.

  • •

    In the comparison of trade-off metric, our approaches outperform baselines on three datasets at different Top-N metrics (5, 10, 20). That is, in line with their inherent modeling of both quality and diversity, k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP based optimization approaches are better at balancing relevance and diversity, compared to common quality vs. diversity trade-off methods that sacrifice quality for diversity, e.g., SetRank on Beauty and BCE on ML.

(iii) comparison between baselines.

  • •

    In most cases, BPR is more powerful than BCE w.r.t. Top-5 related quality metrics. This suggests that the pairwise ranking BPR enables GCN based CF models to assign user-interested items with high rankings.

  • •

    The m⁢i⁢n𝑚𝑖𝑛minitalic_m italic_i italic_n results mainly occur in BPR and BCE (objective functions based on individual item comparison ), indicating the importance of considering the correlations among items.

To further demonstrate the effectiveness of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP approaches, we conduct more experiments on the basic MF implementation (i.e., directly optimizing the optimization criterion). According to the comparison in Table II, only the two main and most noteworthy variants (PS and NP) of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP are further compared, denoted by Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS. Following previous CF studies [5, 6, 21], only the ranking optimization approaches (i.e., BPR, SetRank, S2SRank) are compared in the implementation of MF. The corresponding comparison is presented in Table III. All experiments are conducted directly following basic MF implementation. The bold values and superscripts denote the same meanings as those in Table II.

The main findings are: (i) NPS type of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP is generally more powerful than PS type w.r.t. quality and diversity evaluation metrics, which reinforces the meaning of taking the items that are of less interest to users in ranking comparisons. (ii) In some cases, BPR achieves the best diversity performance but the worst relevance results among the compared methods, e.g., CC@5 on Beauty and Anime. This might be caused by the application of basic MF, as the simple MF endows embeddings learned from BPR with more randomness compared to other set-level ranking optimization approaches, and therefore diversity is promoted but relevance is sacrificed; (iii) Compared to SetRank and S2SRank that consider the correlations of item sets, around 5% improvement is achieved on overall performance (F). This again verifies the effectiveness of our approaches even deploying them on basic and simple MF. Aligning with analysis from GCN and MF implementations, additional and extensive evidence can be provided to support the superiority of our approaches.

To evaluate the adaptability and generality of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP based approaches for the item recommendation area, we deploy two main types of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP (PS and NPS) on popular CF models (i.e., GCMC and NeuMF) by replacing their original recommendation objective function. If the reworked models that apply Lk𝑘kitalic_kP obtain better performance than the original frameworks, we can validate two advantages of this work: (i) Lk𝑘kitalic_kP can be adaptively applied to existing CF models as an objective function, i.e., can be generalized to distinct recommendation models; (ii) the boosted performance is another evidence to show the superiority of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP.

The corresponding comparison is shown in Table IV, where the methods with subscripts PS and NPS denote the reworked models by Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS, respectively. The bold value is the best among three methods (a baseline and two reworked models on a dataset), since we only consider the improvement achieved by reworked models over the original baseline, the comparison between different baselines is not needed. Improv(%) shows how much Lk𝑘kitalic_kP (the better approach out of PS and NPS) improves over the original baseline. We can find that (i) In most cases, obvious improvements (particularly on beauty dataset) are obtained by the reworked models compared to original baselines on both quality and diversity evaluation metrics; (ii) In the comparison between Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS, NPS type provides better suggestions (more relevant and diversified) for users. This finding is consistent with the results of Table II and Table III.

Overall, the reworked models (Table IV) and GCN-based implementations (Table II) exhibit more pronounced improvements than the basic MF-based methods. This could be attributed to the fact that the simplistic MF might not possess the same representation learning capacity as the neural network-based methods, thereby hindering their ability to fully exploit the relationships captured by set-level ranking optimization. Nevertheless, our approaches consistently demonstrates over a 5% enhancement on both basic and recently proposed neural models in most scenarios. This highlights that Lk𝑘kitalic_kP, which perceives multiple items as a cohesive entity and employs probability distributions for relevance and diversity ranking, is not only effective and but also propels advancements of both recent and classic techniques within the domain.

IV-B2 Analysis

Table II-Table IV have verified the superiority of Lk𝑘kitalic_kP from multiple aspects. We now further discuss the attributes of our approaches. Experiments in Table II-Table IV are conducted under the same setting of k=n=5𝑘𝑛5k=n=5italic_k = italic_n = 5. We use Figure 2 and Figure 3 to illustrate the effects of k𝑘kitalic_k and n𝑛nitalic_n for CF recommendations. Note that the error bars in the figures represent the standard errors. The slightly visible error bars confirm the stability of our experiments. Besides the performance of three evaluation metrics, the epochs that are needed by Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS or Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS to achieve the best performance under each setting are also presented. As Lk𝑘kitalic_kP regards multiple items as a whole and tries to capture correlations among them, we therefore only perform experiments on k>1𝑘1k>1italic_k > 1. The slight decrease of CC results when k>4𝑘4k>4italic_k > 4 might be caused by the correlations among items, as k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP enjoys more correlations for recommendation relevance but lowers the weight of diversity. The quality performance (NDCG@5) clearly increases at first when k<5𝑘5k<5italic_k < 5, but a downward trend happens when k>5𝑘5k>5italic_k > 5. This suggests that if excessive correlations among items are considered, the final performance will be negatively affected. As for the epochs, an obvious trend, i.e., an increase with k𝑘kitalic_k, can be found, which is straight-forward to explain as k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP needing more time to learn the more complex distribution.

Figure 3 shows Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS performance (Top-5 and Top-20) on Beauty with different numbers of unobserved items (i.e., n𝑛nitalic_n). We find that all three metrics at different rankings show a similar trend. That is, they smoothly increase at first and then decrease. These results mean that the moderate size of n𝑛nitalic_n provides a sufficient set-level ranking comparison for learning k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities. However, when redundant comparisons are provided (e.g., n>5𝑛5n>5italic_n > 5), it becomes difficult for k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP to capture effective correlations. As mentioned in Section III-B, we set k=n𝑘𝑛k=nitalic_k = italic_n and the number of targets in the ground set equals to k𝑘kitalic_k for Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS to keep the ranking interpretation. External experiments in the cases of n>k𝑛𝑘n>kitalic_n > italic_k on NPS and the number of targets (6 and 7) >kabsent𝑘>k> italic_k (5) on PS have been performed. However, the worse performance compared to the presented cases suggests the importance of maintaining the ranking interpretation. Experiments in Figure 2 and Figure 3 are conducted on GCN implementation. Similar conclusions are obtained from experiments deployed on MF.

To diagrammatically present the ranking interpretation, we use real examples to show the probability ranking of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP subsets. We randomly select 100 training instances (k+n𝑘𝑛k+nitalic_k + italic_n ground set where k=n=5𝑘𝑛5k=n=5italic_k = italic_n = 5) in the learning process, and divide all k𝑘kitalic_k-sized subsets (252) of a ground set into six groups according to the target number in a subset, e.g., the group of k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets with 1 target comprised of 25 subsets (the subsets filled by 1 observed item and 4 unobserved ones), and target number =5absent5=5= 5 represents the target subset Su+ksuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑢𝑘S_{u}^{+k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT drawn from a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP formulated in Equation 4. The k𝑘kitalic_k targets and n𝑛nitalic_n random items of training instances contain the same number of categories.

Figure 4 presents probability ranking trends of Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS employing GCN at 0, 30, 100, and 200 training epochs on Beauty. To illustrate the ranking interpretation of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability learning, probabilities of 252 k𝑘kitalic_k-sized subsets from each 5+5555+55 + 5 ground set, i.e., C⁢(5+5,5)𝐶555C(5+5,5)italic_C ( 5 + 5 , 5 ) combinations, are calculated. Before the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP learning process starts, randomly distributed subsets (cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k) are assumed to have the equivalent probability of being selected as a k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP, i.e., 0.004 (1/252) for each subset. Each bar in a plot denotes the averaged probabilities of subsets that contain the same number of observed items from randomly selected training instances.

We can see that subsets with differing numbers of targets indeed have close normalized k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities (i.e., near 0.004) when epoch =0absent0=0= 0. With the learning process proceeding, the discrepancy between k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities of subsets with different target numbers obviously grows at first, i.e., subsets with more targets are endowed with higher probabilities, and the trend tends to be stable when epochs reach 200. These illustrate that relevance ranking interpretation behind Lk𝑘kitalic_kP are validated by the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability examples, as the target subset ranks higher (with greater k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probability) than other subsets, and the subset with unobserved items ranks lower than the subsets that contain one or more targets. In addition, considering the exclusion of negative subsets in k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP (i.e., Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS) facilitates widening the ranking gap between target set and unobserved item set compared to Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNS, further enhancing performance improvements (as shown in Table II-Table IV). The similar trends can be found on other datasets and MF implementation.

We also conduct a comparison between the averaged k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities (k𝑘kitalic_k=n𝑛nitalic_n=5) of two types of target subsets on Anime using Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS, i.e., monotonous target subsets with limited categories (<4absent4<4< 4 categories) and diversified target subsets with broader categories (>5absent5>5> 5 categories). The observed average probabilities of 0.0041 vs. 0.0040, 0.0045 vs. 0.0042, and 0.0046 vs. 0.0043 for diversified and monotonous target subsets at 0, 100, and 200 epochs respectively, confirm the significant role of diversity ranking interpretation across (k+n)𝑘𝑛(k+n)( italic_k + italic_n ) k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions in our optimization approaches. Because the diverse kernel 𝐊𝐊\mathbf{K}bold_K is pre-learned, on average, diverse target sets from half of randomly selected training instances (k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions) have a relatively higher probability than other monotonous target sets from the k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distributions of the remaining half, even before the Lk𝑘kitalic_kP optimization begins.

These results again indicate the importance of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP normalization, as only in this case the ranking interpretation is provided. We also perform experiments in the case of removing normalization of k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP, and then two serious problems occur: (i) the deep learning frameworks (both Pytorch and TensorFlow) cannot handle the complex gradient calculation of the DPP, as the non-normalized determinant values are unstable; (ii) even if we use some techniques, e.g., normalizing diverse kernel or adding activation function to control the values of relevance scores, to avoid the gradient calculation error, the final recommendation results still cannot compare with Lk𝑘kitalic_kP approaches, as the important ranking interpretation for personalized ranking is ignored. These also elucidate why the standard DPP is inapplicable for ranking-based optimization criterion. Within the standard DPP distribution, ranking competition arises among subsets of all sizes, leading to an uninterpretable and ineffective ranking optimization (concrete analysis in Section III-B1). According to our experiments under the same setting as Table II-Table IV, applying standard DPP for the ranking probability formulation (Equation 4) achieves an unacceptable performance that is weaker than BPR (0.1106 vs. 0.1254 at NDCG@20 on ML). This is the reason we omit the results based on standard DPP in this section.

In Figure 5, we conduct a case study on u1518subscript𝑢1518u_{1518}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1518 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ML-1M using GCN-based Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS. For clarity, we categorize each movie reviewed by u1518subscript𝑢1518u_{1518}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1518 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a key genre based on its synopsis on Wikipedia. Five genres emerge in the training data, while the test data comprises five movies across four genres. Training movies reveal the user’s inclination towards Sci-Fi (6) and Action (5) movies. Both BPR and S2SRank methods acknowledge this preference by recommending target movies (denoted as 1) in the predicted Top 5 list at positions 2 and 4, and 1 and 3 respectively. Our Lk𝑘kitalic_kP method, while recognizing the user’s apparent preferences, also considers diversity by suggesting a hidden target romance movie. This highlights Lk𝑘kitalic_kP’s ability to cater to relevance and diversity. We also analyze k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP probabilities for 3-sized subsets over movies for testing and observe: (i) The diversified item subset {v1,v4,v5}subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣4subscript𝑣5\{v_{1},v_{4},v_{5}\}{ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } has a higher probability than monotonous ones, affirming our consideration on diversity comparison; (ii) Despite similar category scopes, the subset {v1,v2,v3}subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣3\{v_{1},v_{2},v_{3}\}{ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } possesses a higher probability than {v1,v2,v4}subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣4\{v_{1},v_{2},v_{4}\}{ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, which suggests that a stronger dependency between v3subscript𝑣3v_{3}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {v1,v2}subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2\{v_{1},v_{2}\}{ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } leads to a higher predictive value for v3subscript𝑣3v_{3}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, further emphasizing the capability of concrete set-level ranking to capture intricate relationships.

V Conclusion

In this work, we propose a new optimization criterion Lk𝑘kitalic_kP based on k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP set probability comparison for personalized ranking focusing on implicit feedback, enlightening a new perspective (set-level probability comparison) in the formulation of ranking optimization. Based on this, two ranking optimization approaches Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS are designed that take into account different ranking considerations. As such, multiple observed items and unobserved items are directly regarded as subsets with fixed cardinality k𝑘kitalic_k, and are compared through the ranking interpretation based on the tailored k𝑘kitalic_k-DPP distribution, notably with probabilistic normalization that respects the cardinality constraint. Three levels of evaluation and comparison in the experiments comprehensively demonstrate the superiority of our approaches, and the ranking interpretation is validated through real-world examples. Notably, plugging our optimization criterion into strong baselines provides a ready source of improved performance. Experimental results help us to analyze the different advantages of two Lk𝑘kitalic_kP approaches and provide insight into making selection between them in different circumstances. Lk𝑘kitalic_kPPS and Lk𝑘kitalic_kPNPS also have potential in ranking related tasks, such as Web search [52, 53] and spam detection [54, 55, 56], which will be explored in the future.
